bibl.title: Despatch from Graham C. Campbell, August 19, 1884
Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

correspDesc.correspAction: Secretary of State Washington, D.C. <date when="1884-08-21"

text.body:
<div1 xml:lang="en" type="document"
<pb facs="20170615_145245"
Hon. Secretary of State:
Dear Sir,
My duties call me again to Gaboon, Africa. We expect to sail from New York via Liverport, Eng. the last of this month. I shall be very glad to write any special instructions from you addressed to 23 Centre SL.N.Y. or I will go to Washington if necessary.
The situation there as appears to one and our fellow missionaries seem to warrant French aggression and accession of territory and I firmly believe that they will not use content until the Congo country is under their control. In where of this I have felt that it myself be will for our government
<pb sacs="20170615_145258"
to send to Gaboon someone who might give his whole attention to this matter and while in this country have been on the look out for some one who I could recommend.
A few weeks ago I met a young man, whom I formerly knew in college, a young man of plishing christian charade and mankind ability, who expressed himself of willing to spend a few years there. I therefore recommend Royal F. King, nephew of Hon. William King of Minnesota, either for the position with which you have honor me, which I will gladly resign and accept the Vice Commercial Agency or to any position you might sufice to appoint him. He has seem some service, under the Department of the Interior, among the Indians where the temptations +young male are similar to those on the coast and I therefore recommend him
<pb facs="20170615_145449" as a tried and bare" can this address is Dubith Minnesota and if he should receive an appointment he could be ready to start for Africa within three months.
I have the honor to remain Your obedient Servant Graham C. Campbell U.S. Commercial Agent of Gaboon West Africa.
P.S. There are needed of the Agency nearly all the blank forms necessary in making our a ships papers a common of Stationary and two flags one, about a 12th flag for the flag pole and a small one for the boat about 4th on length.
Graham C. Campbell
